dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, it's finally happening! After weeks of chatter, Vice President Harris is set to unveil this massive infrastructure and manufacturing proposal today.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, it's finally happening! After weeks of chatter, Vice President Harris is set to unveil this massive infrastructure and manufacturing proposal today.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After weeks of anticipation, President Biden will unveil on Wednesday a sweeping proposal to revitalize American infrastructure and manufacturing, begin the transition to clean energy and industry and create jobshere are the details.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's huge, right? Like, we're talking about a sweeping plan to, um, really get the US economy moving again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's huge, right? Like, we're talking about a sweeping plan to, um, really get the U S economy moving again.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the numbers are just wild. Biden's asking Congress for, what, $2 trillion? Over five years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the numbers are just wild. Biden's asking Congress for, what, two trillion dollars? Over five years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $2 trillion Biden will ask Congress to approve for his American Jobs Plan will be spent over a period of eight years and paid for with tax hikes over a period of 15 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Two trillion! And that's gonna be paid for, like, over fifteen years through tax hikes, which is pretty interesting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Two trillion! And that's gonna be paid for, like, over fifteen years through tax hikes, which is pretty interesting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $2 trillion Biden will ask Congress to approve for his American Jobs Plan will be spent over a period of eight years and paid for with tax hikes over a period of 15 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So, big spending now, but the payback period is quite a bit longer. And they've broken down that $2 trillion, haven't they? A huge chunk for roads and bridges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So, big spending now, but the payback period is quite a bit longer. And they've broken down that two trillion dollars, haven't they? A huge chunk for roads and bridges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Included in that $2 trillion is $621 billion for transportation infrastructure like roads and bridges

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, $621 billion for transportation. But also, a significant amount – [interrupts] I saw it was like $174 billion – just for the electric vehicle market, which is pretty forward-thinking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, six hundred twenty one billion dollars for transportation. But also, a significant amount - I saw it was like one hundred seventy four billion dollars - just for the electric vehicle market, which is pretty forward-thinking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Included in that $2 trillion is $621 billion for transportation infrastructure like roads and bridges, with $174 billion of that set aside for the electric vehicle market

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And then stuff like clean drinking water, expanding broadband, power infrastructure... you know, the stuff that really makes a country run.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And then stuff like clean drinking water, expanding broadband, power infrastructure... you know, the stuff that really makes a country run.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...$111 billion for clean drinking water, $100 billion for expanding broadband and $100 billion for power infrastructure like the electric grid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, there's like, $213 billion for affordable housing and a massive $400 billion for the care economy. That's a huge focus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, there's like, two hundred thirteen billion dollars for affordable housing and a massive four hundred billion dollars for the care economy. That's a huge focus.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theres also $213 billion for affordable and sustainable housing, $400 billion for the care economy and $100 billion for workforce development.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. So, to pay for all this, Host_B, how are they gonna do it? Because that's where the rubber meets the road, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. So, to pay for all this, Host_B, how are they gonna do it? Because that's where the rubber meets the road, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. They're looking at raising the corporate tax rate, um, from 21% to 30%. That's a pretty big jump.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. They're looking at raising the corporate tax rate, um, from twenty one percent to thirty percent. That's a pretty big jump.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To help pay for all that spending, the Biden administration is expected to propose a series of major tax changes including raising the corporate rate from 21% to 28% and raising the global minimum tax.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. And a global minimum tax too, I think. So, big companies and wealthy individuals are definitely in their sights.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. And a global minimum tax too, I think. So, big companies and wealthy individuals are definitely in their sights.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...raising the corporate rate from 21% to 28% and raising the global minimum tax. ... While Republicans are sure to balk at the price tag and the potential repeal of many of President Trumps tax cuts for big companies and wealthy individuals to pay for the plan...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. But, you know, not everyone is, um, on board with this. Republicans are already balking at the price tag.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. But, you know, not everyone is, um, on board with this. Republicans are already balking at the price tag.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Republicans are sure to balk at the price tag and the potential repeal of many of President Trumps tax cuts for big companies and wealthy individuals to pay for the plan...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding. They're gonna hate the idea of repealing those Trump-era tax cuts. But then, you've got progressives like AOC saying it's not nearly enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No kidding. They're gonna hate the idea of repealing those Trump-era tax cuts. But then, you've got progressives like A O C saying it's not nearly enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Republicans are sure to balk at the price tag and the potential repeal of many of President Trumps tax cuts for big companies and wealthy individuals to pay for the plan, some progressives are saying the package should be larger. This is not nearly enough, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted Tuesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So, it's a battle from both sides. It really feels like a replay of the American Rescue Plan.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So, it's a battle from both sides. It really feels like a replay of the American Rescue Plan.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The American Jobs plan follows the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan, which Biden signed into law earlier this month. ... The American Rescue Plan was passed by Democrats over the objections of the Republican party using a special legislative process called budget reconciliation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does. And the big question is, will they try to push this through with budget reconciliation again, or will they actually try to get Republican votes?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does. And the big question is, will they try to push this through with budget reconciliation again, or will they actually try to get Republican votes?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not yet clear whether Democrats will attempt to use reconciliation for the infrastructure package or whether they will seek enough Republican votes to pass the bill using the standard process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's gonna be the legislative drama to watch, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's gonna be the legislative drama to watch, for sure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, um, speaking of forward-looking things, I read that analysts think companies making semiconductors, those computer chips, are poised to really benefit from this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, um, speaking of forward-looking things, I read that analysts think companies making semiconductors, those computer chips, are poised to really benefit from this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Analysts from Bank of America predict that companies that manufacture the equipment used to make semiconductorsthe computer chips found in everything from cars to smartphonesare poised to profit from Bidens push to modernize the United States digital infrastructure and shore up domestic production of the essential computer components as part of his $2 trillion plan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's smart, right? Modernizing our digital infrastructure. So, what's next? Is this the whole plan?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's smart, right? Modernizing our digital infrastructure. So, what's next? Is this the whole plan?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, apparently there's a second part coming next month. That'll focus more on healthcare and childcare. So, more to come!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, apparently there's a second part coming next month. That'll focus more on healthcare and childcare. So, more to come!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is expected to introduce the second part of his American Jobs Plan next month. That proposal will include provisions related to healthcare and childcare.
